articles.personality_title: New method uses exoplanet atmospheres to reveal interior states
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists study lava planets, exoplanets with extremely hot surfaces, to learn about their internal composition and conditions. The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) provides detailed atmospheric data that can offer clues about these distant worlds.

**What happened** – Researchers developed a model that uses JWST data to differentiate between lava planets that are molten all the way to their cores and those with solid interiors beneath their molten surfaces. This approach analyzes atmospheric signatures to infer the planet’s internal state.

**Impact** – This method offers a new way to understand the geology and evolution of exoplanets without direct observation. By linking atmospheric data to internal properties, it improves scientists’ ability to characterize planets beyond our solar system, advancing exoplanet science.

**What’s next step** – As JWST continues collecting data, researchers will apply this model to observe more lava planets, refining our understanding of their formation and structure. This could also guide future missions aimed at studying rocky exoplanets in greater detail.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Using atmospheric data from JWST, scientists can now identify whether lava planets are molten deep inside or have solid cores, enhancing knowledge of their internal makeup.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle méthode utilise l’atmosphère des exoplanètes pour révéler leur état intérieur
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques étudient les planètes de lave, des exoplanètes à la surface extrêmement chaude, afin de mieux comprendre leur composition interne et leurs conditions. Le télescope spatial James Webb (JWST) fournit des données atmosphériques détaillées qui donnent des indices sur ces mondes lointains.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs ont développé un modèle qui utilise les données du JWST pour distinguer les planètes de lave entièrement en fusion jusqu’à leur noyau de celles ayant un intérieur solide sous leur surface en fusion. Cette approche analyse les signatures atmosphériques pour déduire l’état interne de la planète.

**Impact** – Cette méthode propose une nouvelle manière de comprendre la géologie et l’évolution des exoplanètes sans les observer directement. En reliant les données atmosphériques aux propriétés internes, elle améliore la capacité des scientifiques à caractériser les planètes au-delà de notre système solaire, faisant progresser la science des exoplanètes.

**Prochaine étape** – À mesure que le JWST continue de collecter des données, les chercheurs appliqueront ce modèle à d’autres planètes de lave pour affiner la compréhension de leur formation et structure. Cela pourrait aussi orienter les futures missions d’étude des exoplanètes rocheuses.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Grâce aux données atmosphériques du JWST, les scientifiques peuvent désormais déterminer si les planètes de lave sont en fusion profonde ou possèdent un noyau solide, enrichissant la connaissance de leur structure interne.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevo método usa atmósferas de exoplanetas para revelar su estado interior
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos estudian planetas de lava, exoplanetas con superficies extremadamente calientes, para aprender sobre su composición interna y condiciones. El telescopio espacial James Webb (JWST) proporciona datos atmosféricos detallados que ofrecen pistas sobre estos mundos distantes.

**Qué sucedió** – Investigadores desarrollaron un modelo que usa datos del JWST para distinguir entre planetas de lava que están fundidos hasta el núcleo y aquellos con interiores sólidos bajo sus superficies fundidas. Este enfoque analiza firmas atmosféricas para inferir el estado interno del planeta.

**Impacto** – Este método ofrece una nueva forma de entender la geología y evolución de los exoplanetas sin observación directa. Al vincular datos atmosféricos con propiedades internas, mejora la capacidad de los científicos para caracterizar planetas fuera de nuestro sistema solar, avanzando en la ciencia de los exoplanetas.

**Próximo paso** – A medida que el JWST siga recolectando datos, los investigadores aplicarán este modelo a más planetas de lava, refinando nuestro entendimiento de su formación y estructura. Esto también podría guiar futuras misiones para estudiar exoplanetas rocosos con mayor detalle.

**Resumen en una frase** – Usando datos atmosféricos del JWST, los científicos ahora pueden identificar si los planetas de lava están fundidos en su interior o tienen núcleos sólidos, mejorando el conocimiento de su composición interna.

articles.title: Sunrise on Crew-11 Launch Attempt
articles.summary: The Sun rises on the morning of July 31, 2025, ahead of NASA’s SpaceX Crew-11 mission launch from NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The launch was postponed due to an unfavorable weather forecast. Teams are now targeting 11:43 a.m. EDT Friday, Aug. 1. NASA astronauts Zena Cardman and Mike Fincke, JAXA (Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency) astronaut Kimiya Yui, […]
articles.content:
NASA/Cory S. Huston

The Sun rises on the morning of July 31, 2025, ahead of NASA’s SpaceX Crew-11 mission launch from NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The launch was postponed due to an unfavorable weather forecast. Teams are now targeting 11:43 a.m. EDT Friday, Aug. 1.

NASA astronauts Zena Cardman and Mike Fincke, JAXA (Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency) astronaut Kimiya Yui, and Roscosmos cosmonaut Oleg Platonov will launch to the International Space Station, where they will perform research, technology demonstrations, and maintenance activities.

Image credit: NASA/Cory S. Huston

articles.personality_title: NASA, SpaceX Crew-11 Launch Delayed but Set for August 1
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA’s SpaceX Crew-11 mission is scheduled to launch astronauts and cosmonauts to the International Space Station (ISS) from Kennedy Space Center in Florida.

**What happened** – The planned July 31, 2025 launch was postponed because of unfavorable weather. The new targeted launch time is 11:43 a.m. EDT on August 1.

**Impact** – The Crew-11 team includes astronauts from NASA, the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA), and Russia’s Roscosmos, highlighting international collaboration. Their mission involves research, technology demonstrations, and ISS maintenance, contributing to ongoing space science and station upkeep.

**What's next step** – The teams will continue final preparations and monitor weather conditions ahead of the new launch date to ensure safety and mission success.

**One-sentence takeaway** – NASA and international partners prepare for the Crew-11 mission launch to the ISS, rescheduled to August 1 due to weather.

articles.title: NASA Installs Key ‘Sunblock’ Shield on Roman Space Telescope
articles.summary: Technicians have successfully installed two sunshields onto NASA’s Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope’s inner segment. Along with the observatory’s Solar Array Sun Shield and Deployable Aperture Cover, the panels (together called the Lower Instrument Sun Shade), will play a critical role in keeping Roman’s instruments cool and stable as the mission explores the infrared universe. […]
articles.content:
Technicians have successfully installed two sunshields onto NASA’s Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope’s inner segment. Along with the observatory’s Solar Array Sun Shield and Deployable Aperture Cover, the panels (together called the Lower Instrument Sun Shade), will play a critical role in keeping Roman’s instruments cool and stable as the mission explores the infrared universe.

To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that

supports HTML5 video This video shows technicians installing two sunshields onto NASA's nearly complete Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope on July 17. The large yet lightweight panels will block sunlight, keeping Roman’s instruments cool and stable as the mission explores the infrared universe. Credit: NASA/Sophia Roberts

The team is on track to join Roman’s outer and inner assemblies this fall to complete the full observatory, which can then undergo further prelaunch testing.

“This shield is like an extremely strong sunblock for Roman’s sensitive instruments, protecting them from heat and light from the Sun that would otherwise overwhelm our ability to detect faint signals from space,” said Matthew Stephens, an aerospace engineer at NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland.

The sunshade, which was designed and engineered at NASA Goddard, is essentially an extension of Roman’s solar panels, except without solar cells. Each sunshade flap is roughly the size of a garage door — about 7 by 7 feet (2.1 by 2.1 meters) — and 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) thick.

“They’re basically giant aluminum sandwiches, with metal sheets as thin as a credit card on the top and bottom and the central portion made up of a honeycomb structure,” said Conrad Mason, an aerospace engineer at NASA Goddard.

This design makes the panels lightweight yet stiff, and the material helps limit heat transfer from the side facing the Sun to the back—no small feat considering the front will be hot enough to boil water (up to 216 degrees Fahrenheit, or 102 degrees Celsius) while the back will be much colder than Antarctica’s harshest winter (minus 211 Fahrenheit, or minus 135 Celsius). A specialized polymer film blanket will wrap around each panel to temper the heat, with 17 layers on the Sun side and one on the shaded side.

The sunshade will be stowed and gently deploy around an hour after launch.

To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that

supports HTML5 video In this time-lapse video, technicians manually deploy the Lower Instrument Sun Shield for NASA's Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope. The test helps verify the panels will operate as designed in space. NASA/Sophia Roberts

“The deploying mechanisms have dampers that work like soft-close hinges for drawers or cabinets, so the panels won’t slam open and rattle the observatory,” Stephens said. “They each take about two minutes to move into their final positions. This is the very first system that Roman will deploy in space after the spacecraft separates from the launch vehicle.”

Now completely assembled, Roman’s inner segment is slated to undergo a 70-day thermal vacuum test next. Engineers and scientists will test the full functionality of the spacecraft, telescope, and instruments under simulated space conditions. Following the test, the sunshade will be temporarily removed while the team joins Roman’s outer and inner assemblies, and then reattached to complete the observatory. The mission remains on track for launch no later than May 2027 with the team aiming for as early as fall 2026.

Download high-resolution video and images from NASA’s Scientific Visualization Studio

The Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope is managed at NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland, with participation by NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Southern California; Caltech/IPAC in Pasadena, California; the Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore; and a science team comprising scientists from various research institutions. The primary industrial partners are BAE Systems Inc. in Boulder, Colorado; L3Harris Technologies in Rochester, New York; and Teledyne Scientific & Imaging in Thousand Oaks, California.

By Ashley Balzer

NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center, Greenbelt, Md.

articles.personality_title: NASA fits crucial sunshields on Roman Space Telescope to protect its sensitive instruments
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA’s Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope is designed to explore the infrared universe. To do this effectively, its instruments must be kept cool and stable, protected from the Sun’s heat and light.

**What happened** – Technicians have successfully installed two large sunshields, called the Lower Instrument Sun Shade, onto the telescope’s inner segment. These are in addition to the Solar Array Sun Shield and Deployable Aperture Cover already part of the observatory.

**Impact** – These sunshields act like a strong, lightweight sunblock that protects the telescope’s delicate instruments from overheating and light interference. Each panel is about the size of a garage door and uses a honeycomb aluminum design to limit heat transfer while remaining very light and stiff. This protection is essential for the telescope to detect faint infrared signals from space.

**What’s next step** – The team plans to join the telescope’s inner and outer assemblies this fall, completing the observatory. After that, it will undergo further testing in preparation for launch.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The installation of innovative sunshields on NASA’s Roman Space Telescope marks a key step toward enabling precise infrared observations of the universe.
articles.personality_title_fr: La NASA installe des pare-soleil essentiels sur le télescope spatial Roman pour protéger ses instruments sensibles
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le télescope spatial Nancy Grace Roman de la NASA est conçu pour explorer l’univers infrarouge. Pour cela, ses instruments doivent rester frais et stables, protégés de la chaleur et de la lumière du Soleil.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Les techniciens ont installé avec succès deux grands pare-soleil, appelés Lower Instrument Sun Shade, sur la partie intérieure du télescope. Ceux-ci s’ajoutent au pare-soleil du panneau solaire et au couvercle d’ouverture déployable déjà présents.

**Impact** – Ces pare-soleil agissent comme une forte protection légère contre le Soleil, empêchant la surchauffe et les interférences lumineuses des instruments délicats. Chaque panneau a la taille d’une porte de garage et utilise une structure en nid d’abeille en aluminium pour limiter le transfert de chaleur tout en restant léger et rigide. Cette protection est essentielle pour détecter de faibles signaux infrarouges de l’espace.

**Prochaine étape** – L’équipe prévoit d’assembler les parties intérieure et extérieure du télescope cet automne, finalisant l’observatoire. Il sera ensuite soumis à d’autres tests avant son lancement.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’installation de pare-soleil innovants sur le télescope spatial Roman est une étape clé pour permettre des observations infrarouges précises de l’univers.
articles.personality_title_es: La NASA instala escudos solares clave en el telescopio espacial Roman para proteger sus instrumentos sensibles
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El telescopio espacial Nancy Grace Roman de la NASA está diseñado para explorar el universo infrarrojo. Para lograrlo, sus instrumentos deben mantenerse frescos y estables, protegidos del calor y la luz del Sol.

**Qué sucedió** – Técnicos instalaron con éxito dos grandes escudos solares, llamados Lower Instrument Sun Shade, en el segmento interior del telescopio. Estos se suman al escudo solar del panel y a la cubierta desplegable ya parte del observatorio.

**Impacto** – Estos escudos actúan como un bloqueador solar fuerte y liviano que protege los delicados instrumentos del telescopio contra el sobrecalentamiento y las interferencias de luz. Cada panel tiene el tamaño de una puerta de garaje y utiliza un diseño de panal de aluminio para limitar la transferencia de calor mientras se mantiene ligero y rígido. Esta protección es vital para detectar señales infrarrojas débiles del espacio.

**Próximo paso** – El equipo planea unir las ensamblajes interior y exterior del telescopio este otoño para completar el observatorio. Luego, se realizarán pruebas adicionales antes del lanzamiento.

**Frase clave** – La instalación de escudos solares innovadores en el telescopio espacial Roman representa un paso crucial para permitir observaciones infrarrojas precisas del universo.
